question_text: How will we be meeting?
neutral_comments: Understanding how to communicate meeting details effectively is crucial for creating inclusive web experiences. Clear and accessible communication ensures that all users, including those with disabilities, can participate equally in meetings or events. This concept is particularly important for people with visual impairments, cognitive disabilities, or those who may have difficulty with specific environments or technologies. WCAG 2.1’s Success Criterion 3.3.1 (Error Identification) emphasizes the importance of providing clear and concise information to assist users in understanding how to navigate a website or application. When meeting information is presented clearly and explicitly, it can significantly improve the user experience for individuals who rely on assistive technologies, such as screen readers, or who may have cognitive challenges. In practice, inclusive design principles advocate for clarity and transparency in communication. By ensuring that all users understand how to access meetings, you help foster participation and engagement, which can have a profound impact on their educational or professional experiences.

answers.comments: Via Zoom (Meeting ID 832-4107-4985) (Weight: 100.0%) [✓ CORRECT]** - This is the best practice for accessibility because it provides clear and direct information about the meeting format and how to join. By specifying that the meeting will occur via Zoom and providing a Meeting ID, users have explicit instructions that they can follow. - This approach helps users with various disabilities, particularly those who rely on screen readers or those who may be unfamiliar with the technology being used. Having the Meeting ID readily available allows users to join the meeting without additional barriers. - This aligns with WCAG 2.1 Success Criterion 4.1.2 (Name, Role, Value), as it ensures that the information is presented in a way that assistive technologies can interpret correctly. - When implementing this solution, ensure that the meeting link is also provided in a clickable format, and consider adding accessibility resources for using Zoom, such as links to accessibility features within the platform.

At Torgersen Hall, Suite 2020 (Weight: 0.0%) [✗ INCORRECT]** - This approach creates accessibility barriers because it relies on physical location without providing any alternative for those who may not be able to attend in person. Users with mobility impairments, visual impairments, or those who may live far away would find this information insufficient. - This option violates WCAG 2.1 Success Criterion 3.3.2 (Labels or Instructions) as it does not offer a clear alternative or guidance for users who cannot physically attend the meeting. - The correct approach should offer both in-person and virtual options for attending the meeting, ensuring that all users have equal access. Including a virtual meeting link alongside the physical address would be a more inclusive solution.

At 801 University City Blvd, Suite 21 (Weight: 0.0%) [✗ INCORRECT]** - Similar to the previous answer, this choice is problematic because it specifies a physical location without considering the accessibility needs of individuals who may not be able to attend in person. This can be particularly challenging for users with mobility impairments or those living in different geographic areas. - It also fails to meet WCAG 2.1 Success Criterion 3.3.2 (Labels or Instructions) as it does not provide adequate instructions or alternatives for accessing the meeting. - To improve accessibility, the information should include a virtual meeting option. This would ensure that all users, regardless of their ability to travel to a physical location, can engage effectively with the meeting.

answers.text: This class is entirely asynchronous.  There are no meetings
answers.comments: This class is entirely asynchronous. There are no meetings (Weight: 0.0%) [✗ INCORRECT]** - This response is also insufficient as it suggests there are no opportunities for real-time interaction, which can limit engagement and connection among participants. Asynchronous classes may not cater to all learning preferences, particularly for those who benefit from real-time discussions and interactions. - This choice does not address the needs of users who may prefer or require synchronous communication for a clearer understanding of course content, violating WCAG 2.1 Success Criterion 3.3.2 (Labels or Instructions). - A more inclusive approach would be to offer a blend of synchronous and asynchronous options, allowing for flexibility in participation while also accommodating those who may have specific needs or preferences for interaction. Additionally, providing resources and opportunities for connection, such as forums or discussion boards, can enhance the overall learning experience.

question_text: When is it acceptable to use CSS-generated content, using the content property with the ::before or ::after pseudo-elements.
neutral_comments: Understanding the appropriate use of CSS-generated content is crucial in creating inclusive web experiences. CSS content properties, like `::before` and `::after`, can enhance visual design without affecting the underlying HTML structure. However, they should not be relied upon for conveying important information that must be accessible to all users, particularly those with disabilities. For users with visual impairments, such as those who rely on screen readers, content generated purely with CSS may not be read aloud, creating barriers to understanding the content. Similarly, users with cognitive disabilities may struggle to interpret content that is not presented in a straightforward manner. The Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) emphasize the importance of providing equivalent alternatives for any content presented non-textually. Specifically, this relates to WCAG 1.1.1 (Non-text Content), which mandates that all non-text content must have a text alternative that serves the same purpose. This principle is not just about compliance but ensuring that all users can access and understand the information presented on a website. Incorporating CSS-generated content must be done thoughtfully, considering how it impacts the overall user experience, particularly for those with disabilities. This aligns with the broader principles of inclusive design, where the goal is to create digital products that everyone can use effectively.

answers.html: When the element displaying decorative content this way has aria-hidden="false"
answers.comments: (Weight: 0.0%) [✗ INCORRECT]** This answer is incorrect because it does not acknowledge any acceptable scenarios for using CSS-generated content. While it is true that CSS should not be the sole means of conveying critical content, dismissing its usage entirely overlooks situations where it can enhance visual presentation without compromising accessibility. This approach may negatively impact users with visual impairments who depend on assistive technologies. If CSS-generated content is used for decorative purposes only, it does not interfere with accessibility. However, if essential information is presented solely through CSS, it creates significant barriers, violating WCAG 1.1.1.

answers.html: When the element displaying informative content this way has aria-hidden="true"
answers.comments: (Weight: 0.0%) [✗ INCORRECT]** This answer is also incorrect because it likely falls into the same fallacy as the first answer, implying that any use of CSS-generated content is inappropriate. This perspective fails to recognize that CSS can be effectively used for purely decorative elements that do not convey critical information. Users with disabilities, particularly those relying on screen readers, would be impacted if essential information were hidden in CSS. This contradicts WCAG guidelines, particularly 1.1.1, which requires that all non-text content must have a text alternative. The correct approach would be to use CSS for decorative purposes only while ensuring that all essential content is accessible through semantic HTML.

answers.html:
When you include the url for links that are only displayed when printing, like so:

@media print {
  a.generated::after {
    content: " ( " attr(href)  ") ";
  }
}
answers.comments: (Weight: 100.0%) [✓ CORRECT]** This answer is correct as it acknowledges that CSS-generated content can be acceptable under specific circumstances, particularly when used for decorative purposes. This practice can enhance visual design without compromising accessibility, as long as it does not convey critical information that users need to access. Using CSS for design elements like icons or visual embellishments that do not carry meaning ensures that the essential content remains available to all users, including those using screen readers. This approach aligns with WCAG 1.1.1, as it ensures that all meaningful content is presented in a way that is accessible. When implementing CSS-generated content, it’s essential to ensure that any significant information is included in the HTML markup. Use ARIA roles or properties to provide additional context where necessary, and always consider how the addition of CSS affects users with disabilities. This practice not only enhances accessibility but also contributes to a more inclusive user experience overall.

answers.text: It is never acceptable to use CSS-generated content.
answers.comments: (Weight: 0.0%) [✗ INCORRECT]** This answer is incorrect because it states that it is never acceptable to use CSS-generated content, which is an overly restrictive view. CSS can be beneficial for enhancing visual design when used appropriately, as long as it does not replace essential text or information. This perspective can create barriers for users who rely on assistive technologies, as it may lead to the exclusion of important content if it is not presented in the HTML. Such an approach violates WCAG 1.1.1, which requires that all non-text content must have a text alternative. The correct approach is to use CSS-generated content thoughtfully, ensuring that any information vital for understanding is conveyed in the HTML itself. This practice helps maintain compliance with accessibility standards and fosters an inclusive experience for all users, reducing the risk of legal implications concerning accessibility non-compliance.

question_text:
What is the matter with the code on this CodePen page?

Checkbox Example

answers.html: The border color does not have sufficient contrast to allow the user to identify the checkbox against the white background.
answers.comments_html: The contrast between the checkbox border (#808080) and the background (#FFFFFF), which is the adjacent color, is 3.94:1.  This is greater that the 3:1 contrast ratio required under Success Criterion 1.4.11: Non-text Contrast.

answers.html: Using Windows High Contrast Mode, when the page is viewed in Microsoft Edge the checkbox would be invisible.
Using Windows High Contrast Mode with the High Contrast White theme, when the page is viewed in Microsoft Edge, the user would be unable to determine whether the checkbox was checked or not.
answers.comments_html: Because the Bootstrap's form-check-input:checked[type=checkbox] pseudo-class relies on the CSS background-image property to indicate that the checkbox is checked and the check in that image is white, users of Windows 10's High Contrast Mode who are using the High Contrast White theme will not be able to see it. This is because the Windows 10's High Contrast White theme changes all background colors to white, including the checkbox background.  This makes the check white-on-white and, thus, invisible.  A similar issue occurs if you choose the Desert theme in Windows 11's Contrast Themes.

answers.html: There is no focus indicator.
answers.comments_html:
The outline property for the :focus pseudo-class is set to dashed black, which ensures that all users know when it has focus.

However, it is worth noting that, by default, Bootstrap's form-check-input:focus pseudo-class sets the outline property to 0.  If this had not been overridden, that would mean that people using Windows High Contrast Mode would not know when the checkbox had focus.

From Laws: United StatesLinks to an external site. in the Deque University course, Accessibility Fundamentals: Disabilities, Guidelines, and LawsLinks to an external site.:

The ADA applies to:

  • Private entities that own, operate, lease, or lease to places of public accommodation. Essentially this refers to businesses and other organizations open to the public, with the exception of religious entities and private clubs.
  • Federal and state government entities.

p {color:#000000; background-color:#4DB396; font-size:1em}
a {color:#6A2C3E}
a:hover, a:active, a:focus { outline: none; border: 0; }

See the published page

answers.text: People using keyboard to navigate the page would not know when focus was moved to the syllabus link
There is insufficient contrast between the non-link text and the background
There is insufficient contrast between the link text and the background
There is insufficient contrast between the link text and the text which surrounds it

question_text:
For the following code, which of the following is NOT true?

<style>
  #steps a { float:right; padding: 0 .5em }
</style>
<div id="steps">
  <a href="3.htm" tabindex="3">Step 3</a>
  <a href="2.htm" tabindex="2">Step 2</a>
  <a href="1.htm" tabindex="1">Step 1</a>
</div>

See the code in JSBin.

answers.text: The first link that will receive focus when the user presses the TAB key will be Step 1
The first content that will be read to a screen reader user on page load is Step 3
The order in which links receive focus when the tab key is pressed is not affected by whether or not a screen reader is running

Setting the CSS flex-direction property to row-reverse rather than using float to change the visual order of the links would have prevented the need to use the tabindex property to change the tab order to match the visual order.

answers.text: The main site navigation menu used on every page in the site has a contrast ratio of 1.5:1.  Changing the color property in a class in a common stylesheet would resolve the problem
A decorative background image that appears on every page of the site that has an alt attribute with the value "background image"

A complex drag & drop widget that allows the user to change the order in which page regions and navigational elements appear throughout a site.  The drag & drop widget is not keyboard accessible and there are no semantics to indicate the appropriate roles, properties, and states of the interactive components in the widget.

There is the ability to add a comment on any page in the site.  The default interface uses a rich content editor that is not keyboard accessible and there are no semantics to indicate the appropriate roles, properties, and states of the interactive components in the editor.  However, there is a toggle button that appears before the rich content editor that allows the user to switch to a simplified interface for leaving the comment that is just textarea tag.

answers.text: Because you would need to use JavaScript to create the expected behavior for a button, such as responding to click and spacebar keypress events

answers.text: You need to explicitly add role=”document” to the <html> tag of all HTML pages in order to ensure that standard document reading keyboard shortcuts are available to screen reader users
The document role is equivalent to the <main> HTML tag
The primary reason for explicitly assigning the document role to an element is to create a document region inside of some other type of region such as an application region
Standard screen reader document reading keyboard shortcuts, such as the ability to navigate by heading, are available in both document and application regions

question_text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding the application role?

answers.text: People can still tab to links and form elements in an application region
People can still activate a link or button in an application region by pressing the Enter or Return key when it has focus
People cannot activate buttons in application regions by pressing the space bar key when the button has focus
People can still use arrow keys to choose elements within <select> lists that appear in application regions

question_text: Which of the following is not a reason why you should generally avoid making a lengthy paragraph focusable solely for the purpose of making it readable to screen readers?

answers.text: Paragraphs are not usually focusable and so users may incorrectly assume that the text they’ve tabbed to is some sort of an interactive control.
Screen reader users may not be able to pause the reading of the text in the paragraph and resume reading where it had paused
Users may not be able to use standard document reading commands that would let them back up a few words and reread content they may have missed.
Pressing the Enter or Return key when a paragraph has focus will always cause any forms in the application region to submit
